idea.title: AI-Powered Clinical Documentation Auditor (Doc Assure)
idea.source: Synthesized from 2026 Healthcare AI Trends / IdeaBrowser unavailable
idea.summary: Real-time auditing layer for AI-generated clinical documentation. As ambient scribes (Nuance DAX, Augmedix, etc.) become standard in 2026, hospitals face a new problem: who validates what the AI wrote? This tool sits between ambient AI output and EMR commit, scoring documentation for clinical accuracy, completeness, coding compliance (ICD-10/CPT), and liability risk. Catches hallucinated medications, missed diagnoses, and documentation gaps before they hit the chart. B2B SaaS: $15/provider/month for clinics, $5K-25K/month enterprise. Distribution: EMR vendors (Epic/Cerner marketplace), ambient scribe vendors as add-on, direct to health systems. 85% of hospitals now use AI documentation — but zero have runtime validation.
idea.healthcareAngle: DIRECTLY aligned with LUMEN SDK thesis. This IS runtime decision assurance for clinical AI — just scoped to documentation. The scoring kernel approach (accuracy, compliance, liability) mirrors LUMEN's multi-criteria decision analysis. Could be: (1) a vertical application built ON the SDK, proving the platform; (2) a partnership play where LUMEN SDK powers the validation layer; (3) competitive intel if someone else builds it first. The market timing is perfect — ambient AI is going mainstream in 2026 but the 'trust layer' doesn't exist yet. This is the governance gap LUMEN addresses. Build it or partner with someone who does.
idea.verdictNote: This validates the LUMEN SDK thesis from a different angle. Documentation validation is RUNTIME governance for clinical AI. Consider: could LUMEN SDK be positioned as the engine that powers products like this?

articles.title: Health Care AI in 2026: Governance and Trust Take Center Stage
articles.takeaway: URAC — the healthcare accreditation body — explicitly calls 2026 'the year of governance.' C-suites are catching up to clinicians who adopted GenAI in 2024-25. The challenge: implementation isn't the bottleneck anymore — governance is. Organizations without clear oversight frameworks are exposed. URAC hints at certification pathways for AI governance. This validates CHAI alignment AND potential accreditation play for LUMEN SDK compliance packs.
articles.linkedinAngle: URAC just declared 2026 the year of AI governance — not innovation. The accreditation body that certifies health plans says organizations without clear AI oversight are now exposed. Certification pathways are forming. If your AI infrastructure isn't auditable, you're building on sand.

articles.title: Clinical AI in 2026: Navigating Law, Ethics, and Accountability
articles.takeaway: Deep dive on the fragmented regulatory landscape — state laws, federal guidance, FDA-cleared vs non-FDA tools. Key insight: the distinction between 'cleared' and 'safe' is blurring as LDT-style AI proliferates. Organizations need governance that connects innovation to compliance AND trust. The accountability question isn't theoretical anymore — it's operational.
articles.linkedinAngle: The FDA cleared it. But is it safe? In 2026, clinical AI lives in a regulatory gray zone: state laws, federal guidance, LDT exemptions. The organizations winning aren't the ones with the most AI — they're the ones with governance frameworks that make 'cleared' and 'safe' mean the same thing.

articles.title: Hospital Trends in Use, Evaluation, and Governance of Predictive AI, 2023-2024
articles.takeaway: Official federal data: Predictive AI in hospitals jumped from 66% to 71% (2023→2024). Billing automation exploded (+25 points to 61%). BUT governance lags adoption — most hospitals still lack formal AI committees. Large hospitals (90%+ adoption) vs small (<60%) disparity is growing. The federal government is now tracking governance as a metric. This is regulatory signal: governance will be mandated.
articles.linkedinAngle: Federal data just dropped: 71% of hospitals now use predictive AI. Billing automation jumped 25 points in one year. But here's the buried lede: most hospitals STILL lack formal AI governance committees. ONC is tracking this now. Translation: governance requirements are coming. Get ahead or get regulated.

linkedin.author: Dr. Rasu Shrestha
linkedin.authorTitle: Chief AI Officer, Atrium Health (Advocate Health)
linkedin.insight: One of the most visible Chief AI Officers in US healthcare. Leads enterprise AI governance at one of the largest health systems (Advocate Health/Atrium). Recent content focuses on responsible AI deployment and clinical AI standards. Frequent speaker at HIMSS and ViVE — potential connection opportunity at ViVE in 11 days. His governance framework thinking could inform LUMEN SDK positioning. Worth a direct connection request with personalized note about runtime decision assurance.

linkedin.author: Dr. John Halamka
linkedin.insight: The godfather of health IT. Now leading Mayo Clinic Platform with explicit focus on AI governance frameworks and trustworthy AI deployment. Posts frequently on clinical AI governance roadmaps and Mayo's approach to responsible AI. His endorsement would be a massive credibility signal for any clinical AI governance product. Follow for strategic trends; eventual warm intro through HIMSS/ViVE networks.

events.name: ViVE 2026
events.description: 11 DAYS AWAY. 9,000+ attendees, 2,000+ C-level execs. Co-created by HLTH and CHIME. AI governance is a major track this year. 1:1 matchmaking available through Provider/Payer Connect program — complete 8 onsite meetings for free pass. Key topics: GenAI, revenue cycle, cybersecurity, interoperability. This is where health system decisions get made. CIOs, CTOs, CMIOs in one building.

events.name: CHIME CIO Boot Camp
events.description: 8 DAYS AWAY. Intimate CIO training and networking before ViVE starts. Leadership training with presentations, discussions, and case studies. Smaller group = deeper conversations = real relationships. Perfect for building trust with target CIO personas before the ViVE chaos.

events.name: HIMSS26 Global Health Conference
events.description: 26 DAYS AWAY. 28,000+ professionals. The largest health IT event globally. 600+ sessions, 1,000 exhibitors. AI governance track, CHAI sessions, Executive Summit. Apple Health's Dr. Sumbul Ahmad Desai keynoting. If you can only do one major conference this year, this is it.

events.name: HIMSS AI in Healthcare Forum - New York
events.description: Curated for senior leaders on AI roadmaps, technology selection, infrastructure, data integrity. Case studies from leading health systems. Smaller than main HIMSS but higher signal-to-noise for AI-specific conversations.

videos.title: Clinical AI Governance: What Clinicians Must Know in 2026
videos.description: Recent podcast episode covering the governance knowledge gap for clinicians. Key themes: distinguishing FDA-cleared from FDA-approved, model drift monitoring, and clinician accountability when AI recommendations are wrong. Practical frameworks for evaluating AI tools in imaging, diagnostics, and decision support. Good primer on how clinicians think about governance — useful for SDK positioning that speaks their language.

videos.title: AI Governance in Healthcare: The PPTO Framework
videos.description: Expert panel on the People-Process-Technology-Operations framework for AI governance. Duke-Margolis is a policy heavyweight — their framing influences FDA and CMS thinking. Discussion covers vendor management, continuous monitoring, and the shift from pilots to production. Implementation — not innovation — is the bottleneck. Directly relevant to LUMEN SDK value prop.

quote.text: Great founders move fast, make decisions, and don't wait for permission.
quote.author: Sam Altman
quote.reflection: Sean — you're back from Bahamas, recharged, and staring down a packed calendar. Oak Valley exec presentation in 7 days. ViVE in 11. HIMSS26 in 26. The federal government is now tracking AI governance as a metric. URAC is building certification pathways. The thesis isn't theoretical anymore — it's operational. The question isn't whether the market wants runtime decision assurance. The question is who moves first. You have the architecture. You have the domain expertise. You have 20 years of healthcare relationships. Sam Altman didn't wait for permission to reshape AI. Don't wait for permission to reshape how healthcare governs it. Ship the SDK. Own the category.
